headline: Herschel Walker says it's 'totally unfair' to ask him if he supports the bipartisan infrastructure bill that passed last year: 'I have to see all the facts'
author: Brent D. Griffiths
sentences: Walker, who's running in the primary for Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock's seat, also suggested the reporter was an Alabama football fan, a reference to Walker's career in Georgia football, which has a fierce rivalry with the Alabama Crimson Tide.
Herschel Walker, who is viewed as a top-tier GOP US Senate candidate, snapped on Thursday when he was asked whether he would have voted for President Joe Biden's bipartisan infrastructure law.

Email address
 By clicking Sign up, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.
In a sign of his campaign's strength, Walker reported raising $5.4 million in the final three months of 2020, a staggering war chest for a first-time candidate.
Former President Donald Trump, who pushed Walker to run, has condemned the proposal after his administration failed to pass its own infrastructure plan.
The Georgia race is widely viewed as one of the key battles that will determine whether Democrats can hang onto their razor-thin Senate majority.
"I think you've gotta be an Alabama fan," the Georgia Senate candidate and ex-football star snapped during an interview when asked about the law.
"I have to see all the facts," Walker told The Daily Caller's Jack Greenberg during an interview when asked if he would have voted for the law.
Warnock and fellow Georgia Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff voted in favor of the bill, but not a single Georgia Republican lawmaker supported it.

Sean Rayford/Getty Images
Walker said he wasn't "privileged" to the facts about the bipartisan infrastructure law that passed last year.
Warnock also helped write an earlier version of one of its provisions, an effort to transition to low or zero-emission school buses.
Warnock's campaign, not to be outdone, reported having $23 million on hand and raised $9.8 million in the same period.
Walker added that he "hadn't been privileged" to have received all the facts in order to give his opinion on the law.
Biden signed the infrastructure bill into law last November after months of debate and stories about its details.
But as McConnell himself has lamented, the legislation became increasingly politicized before its House passage.
Nineteen Senate Republicans, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, voted in favor of the bill.
I think that's what is totally unfair to someone like myself to say, 'What are you going to vote for'?"
Sen. Raphael Warnock, who Walker may face this November, enthusiastically supported Biden's plan.
Trump has gone so far as to push primary challenges for lawmakers who voted for Biden's plan.
Local news reports say Georgia is expected to receive more than $11 billion from the law.
It's not clear what he meant, given that the legislation's contents are public.
